Name.BusinessNameLine1: National Institute for Reproductive Health Inc

IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDescription: Sustain, promote and education about women's reproductive rights
IRS990.MissionDescription: The National Institute for Reproductive Health ("National Institute") is an innovation institute for state and local organizations working on reproductive health issues. We offer strategic guidance, hands-on support and funding to help state and local leaders remove barriers to health care, win public battles and change public policies. We are helping women in communities all across the country gain access to the full range of quality reproductive health care options, the freedom to exercise their reproductive rights and the opportunity to have healthy pregnancies.
IRS990.Description: THE URBAN INITIATIVE FOR REPRODUCTIVE HEALTH: THIS PROJECT WAS OFFICIALLY LAUNCHED AT A NATIONAL SUMMIT HELD IN NEW YORK CITY IN THE SPRING OF 2008 AND ATTENDED BY OVER 200 PARTICIPANTS FROM 36 CITIES. THIS SUMMIT REPRESENTED THE FIRST PHASE OF THE MULTI-YEAR URBAN INITIATIVE TO IMPROVE THE REPRODUCTIVE HEALTH OF CITIES. BUILDING ON THE MOMENTUM CREATED DURING THE SUMMIT, THE NATIONAL INSTITUTE SUPPORTED FOUR REGIONAL SUMMITS THIS PAST FALL THAT BROUGHT TOGETHER ADVOCATES AND PUBLIC OFFICIALS TO DISCUSS IMPROVING REPRODUCTIVE HEALTH POLICIES AND PROGRAMS IN THEIR CITIES AND REGIONS. THESE REGIONAL SUMMITS WERE ATTENDED BY OVER 500 ELECTED OFFICIALS, PUBLIC HEALTH LEADERS AND LOCAL ADVOCATES REPRESENTING 70 CITIES AND 33 STATES FROM ACROSS THE COUNTRY.

Activity2.Description: Teen Outreach Reproductive Challenge (TORCH): In order to reach a wide range of New York City teenagers, peer educators go through a formal application and interview process and are selected from a range of schools with special emphasis on neighborhoods with the highest teen pregnancy rates. The group then participates in a 36-hour, nine week leadership training that emphasizes community organizing, group facilitating, public speaking, peer counseling, and current reproductive health issues. During the last year alone, peer educators conducted over 100 presentations, on topics including Reproductive Health, Keeping it Real With Your Doctor, Human Sexuality 101, Emergency Contraception, Body Image and Self-Esteem, Reproductive Justice, HPV, and Healthy Adolescent Relationships. Peer educators reached thousands of participants of both sexes and a wide age range throughout all five boroughs of NYC.

Activity3.Description: Messaging Project: The recent health care reform debate in Washington, D.C. has put funding for abortion care, both public and private, in the public dialogue at a level not seen in more than 30 years. The National Institute plays a critical role in that conversation through research and message development that works to ensure support for womens access to insurance coverage for abortion care. The National Institute conducted two rounds of focus groups in five markets, including Raleigh, NC, Minneapolis, MN, Denver, CO, Pittsburgh, PA and Kansas City, MO. Participants represented a range of demographic groups, including African-American women, Latinas and Caucasian women, as well as married and unmarried Caucasian men. All groups were comprised of individuals who were aged 30-55 years old, registered voters and insured. The objective of the focus groups was to hone specific proactive messages that people can use to affirm the right to insurance coverage for abortion. Once our research and messages are completed, the National Institute will develop a Messaging Toolkit that will be disseminated to national and local through briefings, a national webinar, and presentations at national conferences.

ActivityOther.Description: The New York State Book of Choices (BOC) is a bilingual (Spanish and English) online resource guide for women who are unsure how to proceed with an unplanned pregnancy and need information about their options. Each year, National Institute staff update the BOC website to include the most current information available about abortion services and providers. In addition to its New York State based work, the National Institute has worked to replicate the BOC model with state organizations across the country. For the past nine years, the National Institute has coordinated the Back Up Your Birth Control (BUYBC) Campaign, the leading national educational campaign to raise awareness of and expand access to emergency contraception (EC). Each year, a partnership of leading advocacy organizations, service providers, campus activists and other community stakeholders conduct educational outreach on the annual Day of Action. Since 2001, more than 350,000 pieces of educational materials have been distributed in more than 30 states. The 2010 BUYBC Campaign focused on the many reasons why women should have affordable and timely access to EC. The National Institute directly addressed these concerns by spreading the word that EC is a safe and effective way to prevent pregnancy after unprotected sex. The campaign highlighted how EC works, who can purchase OTC EC, and sources of free and low-cost EC throughout the country.

IRS990ScheduleA.GeneralExplanation: Schedule A, Part II, Line 10, Explanation of Other Income: Special Events

Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Explanation: Prior period adjustment: In 2006, the former landlord bought out the remainder of the Organization's lease and directed it to vacate the premises by October 2006. To compensate the Organization, a lease buyout payment of $1,675,000 was agreed upon by both parties. This amount was erroneously recorded as deferred rent liability and amortized over the life of the new lease. As of June 30, 2009, the balance remaining was $1,220,454, which is reflected as a restatement in the statement of activities. In addition, an adjustment of $969,000 was made to correct an underaccrual of government grants relating to prior years. The total restatement was $2,189,454. Additionally, net asset classifications were restated.

Form990ScheduleIPartIV.Explanation: The National Institute issues a Request for Proposals (RFP) from 501(c)3 organizations around the country interested in implementing a specific project related to our program. The RFP delineates specific guidelines the organization must meet in order to qualify, including budget, timeline, project goals, evaluation plans and organizational overview. The submitted proposals are then reviewed by a staff committee and ranked based on several criteria. The staff recommendations are reviewed by the President, who makes the final decision. All groups that receive financial support from the National Institute are required to sign a Memorandum of Understanding and submit a detailed strategic plan that includes a set of specific goals and deliverables throughout the course of the project. The National Institute staff holds regular conference calls and, where appropriate, site visits. At the conclusion of all grant cycles, grantees are required to submit a detailed report that includes an evaluation and financial accounting of the grant.

Form990ScheduleJPartIII.Explanation: FIRST-CLASS TRAVEL WAS PROVIDED TO KELLI CONLIN. THIS WAS TREATED AS A NONTAXABLE BENEFIT. PAYMENTS IN CONNECTION WITH TRAVEL FOR COMPANIONS AND BUSINESS USE OF PERSONAL RESIDENCE WERE PROVIDED TO KELLI CONLIN. WITH REGARD TO THE TAX IMPLICATIONS OF THESE PAYMENTS, REFER TO THE EXPLANATION PROVIDED IN SCHEDULE O FOR SCHEDULE l, pART I, EXCESS BENEFIT TRANSACTIONS.

The above activities did not follow a written policy. National institute for reproductive health, inc. is currentrly formalizing a written policy regarding controls and oversite over executive spending.

DQPTable.DescriptionOfTransaction: Defalcation of assets - In 2011 the manhattan district attorney conducted an investigation into the expenditures of the executive director of the organization, Kelli Conlin. Kelli pleaded guilty to felony falsifying business records. This matter was settled, and Conlin agreed to reimburse the organization in the amount of 75,000 dollars. In addition an Investigation is currently being conducted by the NYS attorney general regarding the recovery of further amounts from Kelli Conlin during this period.

Form990ScheduleMPartII.Identifier: Method for Determining Number of Contributors:
Form990ScheduleMPartII.Explanation: Line 9, Column (b): This number represents the number of contributors.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 11
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: Senior staff reviews the 990, which is then sent to the Board Finance Committee for additional review and approval. Upon the committee's satisfaction, 990s are presented to the entire Board.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 12c
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: Disclosure by Board members is updated at least annually. Disclosure of all facts pertaining to potential conflict shall be made to the Board. Fact gathering and review by the Board determines if conflict exists. The Board shall determine by a majority vote of the disinterested directors whether the transaction or arrangement in the Corporation's best interest.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 15
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The compensation of the organizations president and other officers and key employees is determined by the executive committee using data from published sources including the non profit coordinating committee. THe president of the organization is responsible for providing evaluations for all vice presidents, which are subsequently reviewed and approved by the executive committee of the board of directors. The executive committee is also responsible for conducting an annual in-person review of the president. Annual salary increases and bonuses for all members of senior management are discussed and approved by the executive committee. This process was last conducted in June 2010

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section C, line 18
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The Organization's form 990 is available online at guidstar.com or the website of the new york state attorney general, and the annual audited financial statements are available upon request

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section C, line 19
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The organization makes all documents available upon request to supporters, donors and government entities but does not make these documents available to the general public.
The process has not changed from the prior year.

Part VII Hours worked in related Organization Kelli Conlin worked 2 hours a week for a related Organization. Edward Leibman worked 1 hour a week for a related Organization. Andrew Stern worked 4 hours a week for a related Organization.

Form990ScheduleRPartII.PrimaryActivities: To preserve and expand the full range of reproductive health care
